pros: Flexible, open and approachable, feel well supported on disclosure of my disability from management. I feel I have grown since starting with RBL and colleagues are knowledgeable in their field and friendly.
cons: processes in systems can be a little time consuming, there could be more benefits such as private health care for all staff as optional benefit to pay into rather than senior leaders only, possibly retention bonus, and opportunities to come together other than monthly days - such as team event days.

pros: I worked with some good people that were a credit to RBL but were often unrecognised for it.
cons: There are serious institutional issues at RBL with regard to bullying and very poor leadership skills, stretching across a number of functions. Working there has been a dispiriting experience for me and profoundly damaging to my mental health; leadership need to refocus on their people rather than their own careers if the organisation is to even begin to be caring and supportive to its staff in the way it aspires to be with its beneficiaries. Online platforms and well being resources are not a substitute for genuinely caring leaders who prioritise and support their people.

pros: Lovely people, with real sense of mission and purpose Being part of national moments of Poppy Appeal and Remembrance feels very special Likeable CEO Org has a prestigious reputation Generally excellent work/life balance although this may depend where in the org you work
cons: Can often feel chaotic behind the scenes Senior management can be obscure and not very visible Prestige and reputation comes at cost - little innovation, slow moving, not very diverse org

job_title: Case Officer in Newcastle upon Tyne, England
pros: We have a specific ask for you this month: please could you ‘review’ RBL on Glassdoor? As you may know, Glassdoor is a key platform for many jobseekers to assess prospective employers – and can be a bit of a snake-pit for people leaving their job to sound off in. Our overall rating and the things that some reviewers have said about RBL don’t reflect that 72% of our colleagues said they ‘would recommend working here’ in our recent employee engagement survey… so we’re keen to have existing employees who haven’t left also have their say. Thanks.
cons: Awful place to work, continual change.

pros: Love spending time with patrons
cons: None that I can think of

review_title: A passionate and wonderful place to work.

pros: Highest salary benchmarked in the charity sector with benefits including London Weighting. Friendly colleagues. Great in-house training such as Mental Health First Aid in the Workplace/Armed Forces Community.
cons: Limited opportunities for career development, with a tight ring-fenced management circle. Diversity & Inclusion is a working progress, yet isn't at all reflected across Executive Leadership.

review_title: Depends what bit you work in

Some managers very supportive - I think your experience will really vary though depending on who you get
Hybrid working, and flexible working available
London office well equipped and nice building to work in
Colleagues are really lovely and passionate about what they do
Genuine desire at the moment to change things, pockets of great initiatives across organisation
cons:
Leadership not always good at being transparent with plans
Often seems beholden to a blinkered and very vocal section of membership
I've not personally experienced bullying/racist/misogynist behaviour but I hear about it all too often from other colleagues
Pockets of great initiatives but not always clear how it helps the whole
Not a lot of clear progression routes within organisation, although you can get some great experience that can help you move on to elsewhere

review_title: Everyone is actively looking to leave :(

Amazing charity with amazing results.

You can buy holidays.
cons:

Too much admin
Nobody knows what’s going on
Under-appreciated
Demotivated
No transparency 
Complete chaos 

Such a  shame as most of us love working here. Even though the salary is much lower that industry standard. 

We are passionate fundraisers who are over worked and underpaid. Losing staff at an outrageous rate.

Honestly wait until 2022 if you are thinking of applying here. Every day, colleagues are breaking down and crying. So many off sick too. 

Such a shame :(

pros: Brilliant staff on the ground who really care about the beneficiaries.

review_title: Are you anyone other than an older, white male? If so, avoid at all costs!
pros:
The only pros:
- Some individuals who work for the Legion, usually entry-level or some mid-level staff who are genuinely lovely people make it *almost* bearable to work there but the charity soon beats out any passion from those individuals too so it's not enough to stay for some of the amazing people you *may* be lucky enough to come across.
- London weighting. Without this, no job role under Head of Department is worth the pay for the amount of work you're expected to do or amount of stress you're put through.
- The recent improvements in maternity benefits.
- Being allowed to have flexible working since lock-down came to an end. Although COVID has been a traumatic and devastating experience, a silver lining for London based workers is that the Legion *had* to allow it's staff to work from home and so without that, some people-managers would've continued to micromanage individuals and insist that lower-level staff cannot work remotely (even though it would've helped those of us with children to have a better work-life balance). Hopefully the organisation recognises now the positive impact that flexible/remote working can have.
cons: Too many to list but if you're a young, passionate individual with a modern way of thinking, or you identify as a woman and would be in an entry or mid-level position, or have an ethnically diverse background, you will not be valued at the Legion. The charity had recently promised to focus on more diversity and had apparently been looking to tackle inappropriate behaviours but they continued to keep and nurture individuals in leadership positions who are dominating and intimidating, sexist, racist and have a complete lack of interpersonal skills, therefore continuing to foster a toxic culture at the Royal British Legion.

I asked if other work could be found and management told me to go during a pandemic when they could have found other work or at least put me on furlough till the busy remembrance period. There is also a very unwelcoming cliquey atmosphere. When coming in the morning no one would be say good morning or how are you unless they were your friend. Overall a very superficial and corporate environment to work in.

pros:
An amazing charity and I’m proud to work here. 

Apparently have to right 20 words, sadly can’t think of any more pros!
cons:
So many layers of management that nothing actually happens. The whole response to employees and beneficiaries during the recent Covid situation was weak and ineffectual. All smoking mirrors and secrets. Nobody knew who was on furlough and indeed if they could volunteer to go on it. 

Management weak and inefficient. Every month there seems to be another layer of management or team leader or even senior team leader added to the structure. So no one actually knows what’s going on or can make a decision. 

There is a culture of passive aggressive management style, although there are hundreds of genuinely amazing people who work here. The pay is abysmal so you find there are two types of people who work here, those who are passionate about supporting our vets and those who can’t get a job anywhere else.

Very very high turnover of staff as employees get frustrated about bad management. I would not recommend working here.

review_title: Constantly re-inventing the wheel as a result of high staff turnover

cons: High staff turnover. Low to middling pay. Mostly mediocre (at best) management - only about a quarter are worth the money they are paid. No other benefits than those mentioned above.

pros: Good working environment, dedicated shop floor level staff

pros:
9-5 hours.

Not too difficult to make friends with people on the same level as you.

If you are just looking for a job where you can float by whilst you focus on something personal outside of work, perhaps the place for you.
cons:
Higher ups completely hostile to idea of flexi time despite "agile working" office development.

Awful HoD who is either incompetent or has no experience in managing teams. They appear to not understand how to measure performance so they base it on presenteeism. Very cliquey. 

Office environment poor - no air flow, poor lighting.

Very hierarchical, resistant to change.

Complaints raised about HoDs by multiple people never go anywhere - sense of them being protected.

No tangible benefits - not even a cycle to work scheme.

Useless meetings. HoD seems to just create work for no reason. Inflexible.

No career options/path for progression. High turnover of staff.

review_title: Good working environment, low pay, generally crap top management.

Too many chiefs (jobs for the boys it seems) and not enough indians. About one third of the high level management are competent the rest are largely hooray henries who have got and hold onto there positions on the basis of the old pals act.

review_title: Harassment, amidst chaos and Bullying in Southport.
pros: Some great staff, and the customers were brilliant. I'd have stayed for the laughs I shared with those folks, really positive. Previous Management and the Head Housekeeper were brilliant, they really pushed for the staff.
cons:
The management change. It all went to hell after Previous GM left, lots of changes and fluctuation, and it all rolls down hill. We caught it all, then they put a new permanent GM in and they targeted certain staff, severely.

Some staff were pushed, others couldn't stand the atmosphere, and now very few are left, and fewer still are happy there.

This place makes me laugh, 'Hotel with a Heart' they say, but the pulse has most definitely stopped.

review_title: would rate 2.5 stars if there was that option

cons: under paid staff hence high turnover of employees. ridiculous salaries to overpaid consultants who brought no value to the charities. nepotism and jobs for the boys. Hesitant to cry racism, but in one department everyone on one side of the room had higher salaries and white skin. The other side was all ethnic minorities but one - that person had the managerial job. funny coincidences... also the ethnic minorities seem to get moved sideways or backwards and never promoted.

pros: The goals of the charity are commendable and the welfare support they provide is excellent. Overall I did feel like my work was contributing to a worthy cause. I had access to excellent external training that gave me invaluable skills, allowing me to progress in my career.
cons: Some teams (including mine) had a negative atmosphere. The senior managers in my team treated juniors and middle managers like children, which led to more than half of the team quitting within a few months. Hopefully the working environment has changed since early 2018.

pros: Fantastic, hard working, operational and frontline staff.

Dreadful bullying behaviour, but they go on and on about the company values - one of them being 'value our colleagues'.   Completely ignored.  And the DG just sits there and lets it happen.

pros: Cannot think of any pros

Work loads are increased heavily for staff members who dont fit in to  their pathetic ideas. Bullying and harrassment is used to force these members of staff out,even to the point of favoured  staff members relaying gossip to managers and it being used  to create outrageous disciplinaries which are often not addressed in the correct manner, HR being so one sided and of no experience in these matters. Disgusting behaviour by whole management team and their favoured staff informers, awful place to work !!!!!

pros:

Nice people to make friends with.

Waste of your supporters money hiring expensive consultants when not needed. Spend hige amounts on annual conferences to alton towers for 3 days when not beneficial. Money could be spent on ex armed forces who genuinely need it.

review_title: Poor management at break centre, Byng House
pros: None that I can think off
cons:
No respect to current members of staff, management have own agendas and make the break centre feel more like a dictatorship than anything else. 

You say something to your manager and you are systematically belittled until you hand your notice in. 

Members of management spend more time writing pointless emails about rubbish and leave the staff to struggle through when short staffed, when the only reason why we are short staff is that the rota does not meet the business needs.

pros: Some really great and dedicated to the cause people working there. You get the sense that these are the people driving things forward with easy success.
cons: Unfortunately there is a lot of bureaucracy which is handcuffing the staff to do even better. Appointing consultants who tell you what the staff have been saying for years is also a kick in the teeth.

review_title: Shameful hideout for bullies, bad managers, wastrels and spendthrifts
pros: err, none that I have seen in my time there
cons:
They splash money around like there's no tomorrow, money given by you, the generous British public.  Many conferences held during each year to which attendance by staff from all over the country is compulsory. £120k spent for a recent 'jolly' 
Regional managers are bullies and massively under-qualified. AD level are only interested in their own little silo and manage that with bullying - you are not allowed to have a different opinion from theirs.
If you get into a fix, don't expect any support whatsoever

pros: Great environment with friendly people willing to help. Also great work life balance, interesting business model.
cons: Limited progression opportunities for those who want to continue education or get involved in mor tasks.

review_title: Much needs to be changed at the Legion
pros: - You might be working with someone who really cares and is passionate about what the Legion represents and therefore there is an emotional connection to its cause
cons:
- The Legion was originally to set up to remember those fallen during WW1 and WW2 over 100 years and now possibly struggling to understand its purpose and existence  onwards

- Too much emphasis during Poppy Appeal and Remembrance means that the rest of the year there is a slack attitude to work.    This means some people and some departments are not really doing much for the rest of the year and an attitude of complacency sets in.

- Short sightedness - everything seems always left to the last minute and not doing things as effectively and efficiently as they should therefore setting in unnecessary panic, chaos and stress.  End result is either recruit internally or usually go and get expensive contractors if its a resource issue

- Pay will not be great because you are working in the Charity sector.   You will have to accept this before you join which some people don't.  Even so having too many contractors does not help continuity either 

- Incompetency is rife because of the lazy attitude within the Legion - too often managers cannot be bothered with doing a proper recruiting process and paying for someone with better skills, experience required to do the role.  So end up with promoting people within who are actually found to be inept, useless, inexperienced and clearly not suited and who have no right or credibility to be given the job. Worst decision I've seen was promoting someone who had not completed their probation because their manager was asked to step up just to save recruitment fee and needing to pay for 1 more person's salary .  An absolute ludicrous and disastrous decision always shows how out of touch some management are.  Even worse was allow these people to waste money and nothing done about that when it was clearly detrimental to the Legion.

- Senior Managers show little interest and do not do enough and act decisively to recognise when something is wrong to take corrective action and therefore everything is always left in a complete mess and create too much uncertainty.

-Lack of decisions and directions from Senior Management means you either have people in their jobs who are lazy, underachievers or inept or wastrels, spendthrifts - both types do not justify their pay

-Some departments are weak because there have been too many changes and they are out of touch and not kept pace with what is going around the rest of the organisation this makes cross functional working relationship difficult

- Work Life balance - if this begins to suffer then my advice would be to leave as not enough is done to help individuals

- Bullying culture - you might be left to fend for yourself if things get tough as not enough is done to stop this behaviour nor support from line manager.    I did not even get feedback and felt isolated from key discussions to help with the direction of the team.  Worst was felt always get blamed for things went wrong and easily picked on whilst others were clearly being protected nor was my manager willing to show leadership skills which includes empathy, objectivity, being listened to and able to get the team working together because it meant others having to work harder or change their own (selfish) behaviours

- No real training or career progression programmes in place  

- High staff turnover -  this is not surprising given the above things seems to always happen

review_title: Byng House - break centres across Legion

cons: Bullying is rife from senior management who manage through fear and threat, creating a controlling environment. HR are part of the problem as no one is listening. Multiple complaints have been lodged yet problems persist. New staff are victimised with no where to go. Huge staff turnover - in management!! Something is seriously wrong.
